docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You did a great service in highlighting the importance of mourning pregnancy losses (front page, Jan. 25). Regardless of the gestational age and circumstances of the pregnancy loss, many parents are confused about what to feel. It is common to experience a wide range of feelings. However, I was struck by the mention of ''overmourning.'' Because this loss can be so profound and unlike any other, it often takes a long time to process the feelings.
docs.abstract: Hillary Grill letter contends that Jan 25 article did great service in highlighting importance of mourning pregnancy losses

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article on new rites of mourning for lost pregnancies (front page, Jan. 25) tells of a means for releasing grief that I discovered last March. Every year for 32 years, on the anniversary of my stillborn baby, I would get sick from repressed grief. Last March, with the help of my rabbi, I created a service to name the baby and to mourn her death. The service included the traditional Jewish mourners' prayer, the Kaddish. Last March 11 I did not get sick, and every year I will now say Kaddish and remember Tzefira in a healthier way.

headline.main: Grieving Pregnancy Loss; Rituals Can Help

docs.abstract: Adela Oliver letter comments on Jan 25 article on new rites of mourning for lost pregnancies

docs.lead_paragraph: The leaders of both parties in the New Jersey Assembly said today that they expected to pass a law requiring women to wait 24 hours before having an abortion, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she would support it. Nineteen other states, mostly in the South and Midwest, have imposed similar waiting periods, which abortion rights supporters say discourage women from seeking abortions. But opponents of the procedure say that making women have second thoughts before having an abortion is exactly their intent.

headline.main: Trenton Bill Would Require Abortion Wait
